factoid: Dólokhov muttered “No‑o‑o!” through his teeth.
Dólokhov said “no, it’s not over.”
Dólokhov stumbled a few staggering steps right up to the saber.
Dólokhov sank on the snow beside the saber.
Dólokhov’s left hand was bloody.
Dólokhov wiped his bloody left hand on his coat.
Dólokhov supported himself with his left hand.
Dólokhov’s frowning face was pallid.
Dólokhov’s face quivered.
Dólokhov began to say “Plea….”
Dólokhov could not at first pronounce the word “please.”
Dólokhov uttered “Please” with an effort.
Pierre was running toward Dólokhov while hardly restraining his sobs.
Pierre was about to cross the space between the barriers when Dólokhov cried “To your barrier!”.
Pierre grasped the meaning of Dólokhov’s cry.
Pierre stopped by his saber.
Only ten paces divided Dólokhov and Pierre.
Dólokhov lowered his head to the snow.
Dólokhov greedily bit at the snow.
Dólokhov raised his head again.
Dólokhov adjusted himself.
Dólokhov drew in his legs.
Dólokhov sat up seeking a firm center of gravity.
Dólokhov sucked and swallowed the cold snow.
Dólokhov’s lips quivered.
Dólokhov’s eyes were still smiling.
Dólokhov’s eyes glittered with effort and exasperation.
Dólokhov mustered his remaining strength.
Dólokhov raised his pistol.
Dólokhov aimed his pistol.
Nesvítski shouted “Sideways! Cover yourself with your pistol!”.
Denísov shouted “Cover yourself!” to his adversary.
Pierre had a gentle smile of pity and remorse.
Pierre’s arms and legs were helplessly spread out.
Pierre stood with his broad chest directly facing Dólokhov.
Pierre looked sorrowfully at Dólokhov.
Denísov closed his eyes.
Rostóv closed his eyes.
Nesvítski closed his eyes.
Denísov, Rostóv, and Nesvítski heard a report at the same instant.
Dólokhov made an angry cry at the same instant.
Dólokhov shouted “Missed!”.
Dólokhov lay helplessly face downwards on the snow.
Pierre clutched his temples.
Pierre turned around and went into the forest.
Pierre trampled through the deep snow.
Pierre muttered incoherent words “Folly... folly! Death... lies...”.
Pierre repeated the words “Folly... folly! Death... lies...”.
Pierre puckered his face.
Nesvítski stopped Pierre.
Nesvítski took Pierre home.
Rostóv drove away with wounded Dólokhov.
Denísov drove away with wounded Dólokhov.
The wounded Dólokhov lay silent in the sleigh with closed eyes.
The wounded Dólokhov did not answer a word to the questions addressed to him.
When the wounded Dólokhov entered Moscow, he suddenly came to.
The wounded Dólokhov lifted his head with an effort.
The wounded Dólokhov took Rostóv by the hand.
Rostóv was sitting beside the wounded Dólokhov.
Rostóv was struck by the totally altered expression on Dólokhov’s face.
The expression on Dólokhov’s face was rapturous and tender.
Rostóv asked “Well? How do you feel?”.
Dólokhov said “Bad! But it’s not that, my friend—”.
Dólokhov spoke with a gasping voice.
Dólokhov said “Where are we? In Moscow, I know.”
Dólokhov said “I don’t matter, but I have killed her, killed...”.
Dólokhov said “She won’t get over it! She won’t survive....”.
Rostóv asked “Who?”.
Dólokhov said “My mother! My mother, my angel, my adored angel mother.”
Dólokhov pressed Rostóv’s hand.
Dólokhov burst into tears.
Dólokhov explained to Rostóv that he was living with Dólokhov’s mother.
Dólokhov said that if Dólokhov’s mother saw him dying, she would not survive it.
Dólokhov implored Rostóv to go on and prepare Dólokhov’s mother.
Rostóv went ahead to do what was asked.
Rostóv learned that Dólokhov was a brawler.
Rostóv learned that Dólokhov was a bully.
Rostóv learned that Dólokhov lived in Moscow with an old mother.
Rostóv learned that Dólokhov lived in Moscow with a hunchback sister.
Rostóv learned that Dólokhov was the most affectionate son.
Rostóv learned that Dólokhov was the most affectionate brother.
Pierre had rarely seen his wife alone of late.
Pierre's house was always full of visitors in both Petersburg and Moscow.
The night after the duel, Pierre did not go to his bedroom.
Pierre remained in his father's room, a huge room where Count Bezúkhov had died.
Pierre lay down on the sofa intending to fall asleep and forget what had happened to him.
Pierre could not fall asleep.
A storm of feelings, thoughts, and memories arose within Pierre.
Pierre could not remain in one place.
Pierre had to jump up and pace the room with rapid steps.
Pierre seemed to see his wife in the early days of their marriage.
Pierre saw his wife with bare shoulders and a languid, passionate look on her face.
Pierre immediately saw beside his wife Dólokhov’s handsome, insolent, hard, and mocking face as he had seen it at the banquet.
Pierre saw Dólokhov’s face pale, quivering, and suffering as it had been when he reeled and sank on the snow.
